item.title: .NET 💜 GitHub Actions
item.description: Hi friends, I put together two posts where I’m going to teach you the basics of the GitHub Actions platform. In this first post, you’ll learn how GitHub Actions can improve your .NET development experience and team productivity. I’ll show you how to use them to automate common .NET app dev scenarios with workflow composition.

item.title: Why Can’t We Agree On What’s True? | Dr. Ian O'Byrne
item.description: This is not as simple as distrust. Digital platforms and ubiquitous access to these spaces have ushered in a new public mindset that ends in a refusal to accept any mainstream or official account of the world. This also includes being instinctively suspicious of anyone claiming to describe reality in a fair and objective fashion.
item.author: (wiobyrne)

item.title: How to be miserable after a breakup
item.description:
1. Text her, often You don't want her to get away. There's probably still hope. Whether you broke up with her or she with you, you need to try everything in your power to win her back. It doesn't matter if she isn't responding -- be persistent.
If she asks you to stop texting her, start calling and leave voicemails. She'll change her mind once she understands how committed you are.
2. Check her social media You need to be on top of this one. As soon as she posts a story on Instagram, watch it. Let her know that you're there and you care. Let her know you're paying attention.
If she posts a picture, like it. If you're feeling extra brave, leave a comment — just an emoji or two is enough. Anything to remind her that you're still out there, thinking of her.
3. Drink and do drugs Drinking is your friend. Alcohol is cheap and does wonders when trying to push the pain away. Maybe start with a fifth of vodka every night?
If you haven't already, start doing drugs. But I'm not talking about weed — weed is for pussies. Buy cocaine, MDMA, and ketamine. Also, make sure you do all your drugs alone. Doing drugs with friends can sometimes be fun, but you don't want that. You want to maximize misery.
If you remember what you did yesterday, you're doing it wrong. Keep drinking.
4. Spend money If you want to maximize misery, you will need to maximize financial problems. You're a grown-up with multiple credit cards, which is basically unlimited money. Why sit on them?
5. Sleep around This one should be obvious. You're single, young, and don't have to spend money on a girl anymore. Download all the dating apps and free up your weekends to go to bars and talk to girls.
The goal here is to push down your fear of being alone through meaningless sex. Also, don't let them spend the night so that you can wake up all alone, questioning when you'll ever find real love again. Now, back to swiping.
6. Drown yourself in work But not in a healthy way. You want to be working at least 14 hours a day. This may sound difficult, but they have drugs for that now. Adderall, Ritalin, Vyvanse, Modafinil, etc. Get a prescription and start consuming. The good thing is that these drugs will suppress your hunger (and passion for anything else), so you can start skipping meals and have more time for work.
7. Make her jealous Post pictures of you with other girls on Instagram. Book a vacation and share photos liberally. Start hitting on her friends -- this is a surefire way of getting her attention even if she isn't looking at your social media.
Do whatever you can to get her attention and make her jealous. This endless pursuit to win her back will bring you misery, guaranteed.
Now, if you don't want to be miserable after a breakup, do the exact opposite of everything above. Delete your social media, stop drinking, stop doing drugs, go to the gym, start meditating, read, learn new things, eat healthily.
You can do this, king.

item.title: Gnome Clipboard History
item.description: Gnome Clipboard History (GCH) is a Gnome extension that saves what you’ve copied into an easily accessible, searchable history panel. The primary innovation over existing clipboard managers is the use of a compacting log for persistent storage.
item.author: (Alex Saveau)

item.title: Eventually consistency and cache
item.description: What is it? Eventually consistency is a fancy name of doing something and only expecting the changed state after a while. And there is a guarantee that you will eventually get the expected state. Hence, consistency. But that won’t work well with caching. And I had to deal with that recently when working with WhatsApp API. When querying for a list of message templates from WhatsApp, we’ll cache the response for use later.

item.title: Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem, in Bash
item.description: Gödel’s first incompleteness theorem states that there are mathematical statements thatcan neither be proven or disproven. His proof is fairly difficult toun...

item.title: Building meaningful relationships with remote colleagues
item.description: I have a diary. I’ve been writing on it somewhat regularly since 2014. I find it extremely useful and I think everyone should at least give it a try. I do it for two reasons: When writing, a diary is a great tool for organizing thoughts and making decisions. The process of writing forces you to articulate thoughts with much greater clarity than you could by just sitting down and thinking.
item.author: (Douglas Vaghetti)

item.title: Going multipath without Multipath TCP
HPKE: Standardizing public-key encryption (finally!)
item.description: HPKE (RFC 9180) was made to be simple, reusable, and future-proof by building upon knowledge from prior PKE schemes and software implementations. This article provides an overview of this new standard, going back to discuss its motivation, design goals, and development process
item.author: (Christopher Wood)

item.title: Moving the kernel to modern C
item.description: Despite its generally fast-moving nature, the kernel project relies on a number of old tools. While critics like to focus on the community's extensive use of email, a possibly more significant anachronism is the use of the 1989 version of the C language standard for kernel code — a standard that was codified before the kernel project even began over 30 years ago. It is looking like that longstanding practice could be coming to an end as soon as the 5.18 kernel, which can be expected in May of this year.
item.author: (By Jonathan CorbetFebruary 24, 2022)

item.title: Firearms have overtaken car crashes as main cause of premature US trauma deaths. Firearm homicides also increased, rising from 11,493 deaths in 2009 to 13,958 in 2018, equivalent to 633,656 years of potential life lost in 2018, up from 554,260 in 2009. : science
item.description: Displaying this as "633,656 years of potential life lost" is completely disingenuous because it does not accurately convey data to the casual observer.
